I've used the same principle with wasp nests for years.  If you can access the nests near your house (obviously not nests way up in the trees), wait till early evening when the wasps have returned home and are resting.  Get a long lighter, the kind used for your fireplace. Put that in your off hand and light it. Get a can of Lysol and put it in your strong hand behind the lighter.

Aim toward the nest and direct the spray slightly above the flame so as not to extinguish it.

You don't have to burn the nest down.  All you have to do is singe the wings of the wasps so that they can't fly. Then when you've got them all, just knock the nest down and discard it.

Works like a charm if you do it right.

They have to burn the nests at night when all of the wasps are in it.

If you have a wasp nest, do this during mid-day.  Use a wet vac with a few inches of water and a few tablespoons of Dawn dishwashing liquid. Attach the flexible tube to a 2X4 of whatever length you need to put the opening of the tube next to the nest.  Turn it on.  Walk away and let it do its work.  The noise will attract the wasps and then suck them up.   The Dawn will cause their exoskeleton to disintegrate.  Leave the vacuum on for a couple of hours.  Give it a short cool down break.  Turn it on again.  Leave for a couple of hours.  The next day repeat. You do need to do this during the day when they are active and out and about. On the third day, at night, soak the nest with wasp spray to get any remaining wasps.  Use your wet vac to suck it up.  I have never gotten stung.  Just have patience. You can watch videos on You Tube with this.  It works. This fire thing is crazy.  You'll burn down the forest.
